column4: hello, i try to make a partition on a disk with gparted, but when it starts creating it the disk automatically mounts and then gparted says it cant create a partition ...what should i do ?
does gparted allow you to umount it again?
not really, it gives an error
gparted can unmount it,and then shows it as if the partition is made, but i cant write anything on it and it contains a file named "lost and found", wierd...
did you boot from the gparted cd or is that not necessary on your computer?
its an external USB disk that i am trying to format with a ext3 partition
i dont know if i should boot from a gparded CD...should i ?
ok, i see... is that really a file named "lost+found" or rather a directory?
no, probably not in case of a usb device, unless you booted from it
a directory,but with a red [x] icon
what does "sudo touch $mountpoint/somename" do?
that sounds like a permission problem, caused by improper mounting, rather than gparted's mistake :)
the mounting is automatic
hm... i am not sure then... maybe it is still mounted by gparted?
no, thats not the case, i closed gparted, i see a volume in my filebrowser, but i cant write on it
can you umount it from the filebrowser?  if not, try "sudo umount $mountpoint"... then unplug and plug the device... maybe that helps, i do not know :)
hmm i tried but no, actually i dont need a partition to dd a disk, do i ?
you can dd into files or raw devices... no need to create a file system
i have a crashed disk and i want to try dd-ing it to this new one...ok i'll try it...was the command this : dd -if /dev/olddisk -of /dev/newdisk ? or do i need to add more stuff ?
i had all that in memo's but they are on the trashed disk ... :/
dd if=/dev/olddisk of=/dev/newdisk bs=4k (or whatever blocksize you prefer), there are also count or offset, but i guess you do notneed them
ok, so bs=4k is good to recover data from a broken disk ?, also do you know anything about what i can do with the image afterwards ? are there tools to recover the actual files from it ?
fortunately i have never had the pleasure to have a broken disk, so no, i am sorry
ok no problem
